claim: Recombinant HA antigens produced using BEVS have been shown to induce significantly higher levels of broadly cross-reactive antibodies against highly conserved regions of HA compared with egg-derived vaccines.
explanation: A multi-panel figure showing hemagglutination inhibition (HI) titers (log2 scale) measured at Day 0 and 1 month post-vaccination in two age groups (18–44 and 45–64 years) for egg-based virus vaccines (left columns) versus cell-based virus vaccines (right columns). Panels are organized by influenza strain (A(H3N2), A(H1N1)pdm09, B/Victoria, B/Yamagata). Each panel shows individual data points, mean ± SD bars for multiple antigens (colored symbols), and p-values indicating statistical comparisons among vaccine and challenge antigens. does not support the claim: the figure compares egg-derived versus cell-derived virus vaccines and hemagglutination inhibition titers, but does not involve recombinant HA antigens produced using BEVS nor assessment of broadly cross-reactive antibodies against conserved HA regions. Note: The image is clear and complete but does not address BEVS-produced recombinant HA or cross-reactive antibody breadth.

Each panel shows individual data points, mean ± SD bars for multiple antigens (colored symbols), and p-values indicating statistical comparisons among vaccine and challenge antigens.
